page.title: 19The Language of Alford
page.content: Alford's best known son is the poet Charles Murray,or Hamewith as he is known.(1864-1941) His work in the rich language of the Vale of Alford has kept alive rural scenes of bygone days.Most local people are bi-lingual in the Doric and English.Many enjoy the church services held in the Doric which are arranged by Dr.Joyce Collie, the local Chuch of Scotland minister. Dr. Collie,one of the editors of the Sottish National Dictionary,has written two Christmas carols in the Doric. Many feel the language is more expressive than English. E.g. skite =to fly off quickly,sough = a murmer or sigh, swak = supple, fair forfochan = exhausted, trauchled = wearied, ferny tickles = freckles, tyauve = struggle.
